cs671

Class Liar<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • cs671.Liar<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Guesser<Liar.Secret<T>>

    public class Liar<T>
extends Object
implements Guesser<Liar.Secret<T>>
    A guessing game for liars. This class implements a guesser that asks questions to a user to find a secret object. The user can lie, but no more than a predetermined number of times. When found, the secret object is returned as an instance of Liar.Secret, which includes the number of times the user lied during the process.
    Version:
    2.3, 01/22/13
    Author:
    Michel Charpentier
    See Also:
    "Paul Hartung, 'Tell all the lies you want - Liars never win', Journal or Recreational Mathematics, Vol. 12(3), 1979-80"

    • Constructor Detail

      • Liar

        public Liar(Set<? extends T> candidates,
    int lies,
    String name)
        Builds a guesser that will find the secret object among a list of candidates, assuming a maximum number of lies.
        Parameters:
        candidates - a list of objects, which includes the secret to be found
        lies - the maximum number of times a use can lie
        name - a word that's used to refer to the objects from the list (string, object, animal, color, ...)
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the set of candidates is empty, the number of lies is negative, or the name is null

    • Method Detail

      • selectCandidates

        public int selectCandidates(int n)
        Sets an upper bound on the number of objects to be used in the guessing process. By default, all the objects provided at construction time are used. This methods selects a randomly chosen subset of objects of the specified size. The selection relies on java.util.Collections.shuffle for randomness.

        For instance, if a Liar object is created with candidates {A,B,C,D} and selectCandidates(2) is called, 2 candidates are chosen (say, A and C) and used for the next game. B and D are then not used at all and won't appear in any question. selectCandidates() should be called after a game has finished and before the next game is initialized. If called at other times, it throws an IllegalStateException.

        The method is most useful when a Liar instance is created with a large set (e.g., a dictionary of all English words) but we care to play with only a few elements from this set (e.g., 10 words, chosen randomly).

        Parameters:
        n - the maximum number of objects to use
        Returns:
        the actual number of ojects to be used in the guessing game; it is equal to n unless the guesser was created with fewer objects
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the object has been initialized and a guessing process is still going on
        IllegalArgumentException - if n is less than 1
        See Also:
        Collections.shuffle(java.util.List<?>)

        Description copied from interface: Guesser

      • yes

        public void yes()
        Description copied from interface: Guesser

      • makeQuestion

        public String makeQuestion()
        Generates a new question. The previous question must be answered (using yes or no) before a new question is generated.

        Note: for testing puposes, the question produced by this method must always be phrased as "Is the secret ... (among) ... ?".

        Specified by:
        makeQuestion in interface Guesser<Liar.Secret<T>>
        Returns:
        the question, as a string to be displayed to the user
        See Also:
        Guesser.initialize(), Guesser.hasSolved(), Guesser.yes(), Guesser.no()

      • progress

        public double progress()
        Description copied from interface: Guesser
        Indicates progress towards solving the problem. After initialization, the value returned is 0 (unless the problem is immediately solved, in which case it is 1). It always increases as the guessing process progresses. It is exactly 1 after the problem is solved.
        Specified by:
        progress in interface Guesser<Liar.Secret<T>>
        Returns:
        a value between 0 and 1 that is a measure of how much progress has been made towards solving the problem
